item.title: Bailout Strains European Ties
item.description: The Cyprus bailout came at the price of deepening the political mistrust between the strong economies of Europe's north and the weaklings of the south.

item.title: Italy Court Overturns Knox Acquittal
item.description: Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito are due to face a new trial on charges of murder and sexual assault for the 2007 killing of British student Meredith Kercher.

item.title: U.S. Warns on Myanmar Travel
item.description: The U.S. Embassy has warned against travel to parts of Myanmar after deadly clashes between majority Buddhists and minority Muslims leave at least 40 people dead.

item.title: Chinese Grads Play It Safe, Lose Out
item.description: Chinese college graduates say they want to work for the government or state-owned firms, rather than the private companies that have powered China's economic climb.

item.title: Kerry Visits Kabul to Bolster Alliance
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry visited Afghanistan to shore up a troubled alliance.

item.title: Spain's Deficit Woe Seen Lingering
item.description: Spain's economy will likely recover at year's end to post modest growth next year, but the country's budget deficit is forecast to remain around current levels, the country's central bank said.

item.title: Cameron Hardens Immigration Line
item.description: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron toughened his stance on immigration with measures to restrict foreigners' access to state support for unemployment, housing and health.

item.title: Egypt Seeks to Arrest Activists
item.description: Egypt's public prosecutor issued arrest warrants for five prominent pro-democracy activists on suspicion of inciting violence during weekend rioting, raising fears of a crackdown against opponents of the politically dominant Muslim Brotherhood.

item.title: Vietnam Boat Claims Chinese Attack
item.description: Vietnam accused a Chinese vessel of chasing and firing at a Vietnamese fishing boat in disputed waters, in the latest flare-up over the South China Sea.

item.title: Mine Chief on Charm Offensive
item.description: Chen Defang, president of a Chinese company at the center of a dispute over a Myanmar copper mine, has launched a public-relations and lobbying offensive to deal with Myanmar's dramatically altered political climate.

item.title: South African Soldiers Killed in Clashes
item.description: Clashes with rebels in the Central African Republic left more than a dozen South African soldiers dead, a setback to the government's efforts to broker peace in the continent.

item.title: Russia Raids Amnesty International
item.description: Russian authorities conducted a surprise audit at the Moscow office of human-rights group Amnesty International, the latest move in what activists say is a widening state campaign against nongovernmental organizations.

item.title: No Sign of Struggle in Tycoon's Death
item.description: Deceased Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky died in a manner "consistent with hanging," British police said in a brief statement Monday.

item.title: Australia to Pull Out of Afghanistan This Year
item.description: Australia said it will withdraw most of its troops from Afghanistan by year-end, after the base from which they operate closes.

item.title: U.S., South Korea Sign Contingency Plan
item.description: The U.S. and South Korea have signed a military contingency plan to respond to possible attacks from North Korea, in Washington's latest step to reassure its Asian ally.

item.title: Guards, Drones to Protect India's Rhinos
item.description: Authorities in India's Kaziranga national park are taking a more muscular approach to combat poachers who have killed 22 one-horned rhinos in the park last year.

item.title: Brics Are Slow to Co-Invest
item.description: Investment among Brics countries remains marginal even as they increase their share of global investment flows, a report shows.

item.title: Wringing Out Laundered Cash
item.description: The U.S. is cracking down on alleged money laundering north of the border by people believed to be affiliated with Mexican drug cartels.

item.title: U.S. Nudges Seoul, Tokyo to Make Up
item.description: Japan and South Korea are haltingly moving to mend their bruised relationship, encouraged by U.S. officials eager to maintain a united front of allies as China's influence rises North Korea steps up its belligerence.

item.title: New BOJ Chief Elaborates on Plans
item.description: Less than a week into the job, Bank of Japan Gov. Haruhiko Kuroda said he will consider buying five-year bonds or longer, his most explicit comments so far about potential fresh policy steps.

item.title: Japan, EU to Start Trade Talks
item.description: Japan and the EU agreed to start negotiations toward a free-trade agreement, a move that follows Tokyo to join talks for a U.S.-led pan-Pacific free-trade pact.

item.title: Brains of Animal Kingdom
item.description: Research shows that we have grossly underestimated both the scope and the scale of animal intelligence. Primatologist Frans de Waal on memory-champ chimps, tool-using elephants and rats capable of empathy.

item.title: China Fashion Week
item.description: New designs from Simon Gao, Wang Peiyi and Gabriele Colangelo during the Mercedes-Benz China Fashion Week.

item.title: Beijing's Spring Snowfall
item.description: Beijing residents woke up Wednesday, the first official day of spring in the Chinese traditional calendar, to a city blanketed in white after an overnight snow storm.

item.title: Diana's Million-Dollar Wardrobe
item.description: Kerry Taylor Auctions expects to raise more than £800,000 pounds ($1.2 million) with the sale of 10 dresses belonging to Britain's late Princess Diana, which are up for auction Tuesday.

item.title: Arms Race to Grow World's Hottest Pepper Goes Nuclear
item.description: The chili one-upmanship raises the question of how many people can actually appreciate the march toward new heights of heat.

item.title: U.S. Soccer Could Use a Good Crisis
item.description: A loss by the U.S. men's soccer team in Mexico on Tuesday would likely revive concerns that this side isn't good enough to make it through an increasingly competitive regional qualifying tournament.

item.title: Photos of the Day: March 25
item.description: In today's photos, a girl poses with a butterfly in London, Spaniards hold Holy Week processions, people apply for unemployment benefits in India, and more.

item.title: Arise! Arise! The British Are…Acting!
item.description: On big and small screens, the juicy Yank parts are going to people with names like Day-Lewis. How to fight back.
